snippet: Private Indian medical schools secretly charged admission fees of as much as $150,000 in addition to tuition, even though India’s Supreme Court banned such fees in 1992, according to two articles published in The BMJ.
abstract: Two articles in journal BMJ describe culture of corruption in Indian medical schools; claim that schools charge illegal admission fees of up to $150,000, turn out underprepared graduates and are subject to political influence.
lead_paragraph: Private Indian medical schools secretly charged admission fees of as much as $150,000 in addition to tuition, even though India’s Supreme Court banned such fees in 1992, according to two articles published in The BMJ.

headline.print_headline: Journal Eyes Corruption in India’s Medical Schools
